wikitext.*:
{{Unnamed}}
The '''language of Dale'''<ref name="Translation">{{App|Translation}}, p. 1135</ref> was the tongue spoken by the [[Men of Dale|Men of]] [[Dale]] and as a [[Northern Mannish|Northern language]], it was related to [[Rohanese]] and, more distantly, to [[Westron]]. 

==History==
Most of the people of [[Dale]] like most of the ancestors of the people of [[Rohan]] were descended from the [[Edain]] of the [[First Age]] or from a people closely related with them. As a consequence, their language was related to the [[Adûnaic]] of the Edain who had migrated to [[Númenor]] at the beginning of the [[Second Age]] and had preserved a likeness to the [[Common Speech]] who was descended from Adûnaic.<ref name="Men">{{App|Men}}, p. 1129</ref>

Many of the high-sounding names of old [[Hobbits|Hobbit]] families, such as the [[Tooks]] and the [[Bolgers]] closely resembled the names of [[Men of the Vales of Anduin|Men]] in the [[Vales of Anduin|Vale of Anduin]] where the [[Éothéod|ancestors]] of the Men of Rohan had lived, in Rohan or in Dale, because most of these seem to have been taken from legends of the past of Men and of Hobbits.<ref name="Translation"/><ref group="note">The relationship of the languages can be seen in [[Brand]], the name of a king of Dale, [[Ferdibrand Took|Ferdibrand]], the name of a Hobbit, and [[Erkenbrand]], the name of the lord of [[Westfold]] in Rohan.</ref>

The language of Dale was adopted by the [[Dwarves]] from that region, such as the [[Dwarves of Erebor]]. In fact they used names from the language of Dale as their "outer" names,<ref name="Translation" /> because it was a taboo to use their true, original names in their own language [[Khuzdul]] when talking with persons from other [[races]].<ref name="L144">{{L|144}}</ref>

The writing system used by the Men of Dale was an old and simple form of the [[Cirth]].<ref>{{App|Writing}}. p. 1118</ref>

==Translation==
In [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]]'s stories names of Dwarves in the language of Dale were represented by names in [[North Germanic languages|Old Norse]],<ref name="L144" /> a language related to [[Old English]] and modern English, because the language of Dale was related to [[Rohanese]] and [[Westron]].<ref name="Men" /> If the language of Dale and the [[Long Lake]] would have appeared in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', it would have been represented as "more or less Scandinavian in character".<ref name="L144" /> In a note on a page dated 9 February 1942 about the fictitious translation of the languages of the Shire, Dale, and Rohan, he specified that the language of Dale<ref group="note">In the note on the page dated 9 February 1942, Tolkien capitalized "Language of Dale", though this is most likely because the "L" is simply at the beginning of the second line.</ref> was represented by Norse and that it was used by the Dwarves of the region of Dale.<ref>{{PM|Languages}}, Commentary, §58, p. 70</ref><ref>{{TI|Notes}}, p. 424</ref> He also stated that Anglo-Saxon (i.e. Old English) is not the source of names in any other language than the language of the Eorlingas except for a few names in Hobbit-dialect derived from the Vale of Anduin, the names Déagol and Sméagol; and the names Gladden River and Gladden Fields.<ref>{{L|297}}</ref>

[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote in his guide for translators for the translation of ''The Lord of the Rings'' into other languages that the name [[Stoors|Stoor]] was based on the early English word ''stor'', ''stoor'' ("large", "strong"), which is now obsolete.<ref>{{HM|N}}, entry '''Stoors''', p. 763</ref>

==Name==
A suggested name for the language of Dale is '''Dalian'''.<ref>[[Andreas Möhn|Andreas Moehn]], "[http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Fr_Atani.html Etymologies of the Atani Languages]" (accessed 26 March 2011)</ref> Another "invented" name commonly used by [[Fandom|fans]] is '''Dalish'''.<ref>"[https://tolkienlistsearch.herokuapp.com/message/5e9c35f9231bf7461a6c91af Breelendish, a Welsh-style Conlang]" (message 33106; 12 March 2006) at [[Elfling]] mailing list (accessed 27 March 2011)</ref><ref>"[https://tolkienlistsearch.herokuapp.com/message/5e9c35b83ee6a6c41e986689 Scandinavians in Middle-earth?]" (message 1075; 15 July 1999) at [[Elfling]] mailing list (accessed 27 March 2011)</ref>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
An earlier manuscript version of what would later become Appendix F states that the name Stoor seemed to have originally meant "big" and that this word was common in "the language of Dale".<ref>{{PM|Languages}}, manuscript F 2, §24 </ref> This version also mentions that Scandinavian stor- means "big".<ref>{{PM|Languages}}, manuscript F 2, §56</ref>

An earlier manuscript version of what would later become the chapter "[[A Knife in the Dark]]" mentions that ''Cram'' was a word in the language of the men of Dale and the Long Lake.<ref>{{RS|Attack}}, p. 177</ref> In the final published version of the chapter "[[Farewell to Lórien]]", [[Gimli]] only says after trying ''[[lembas]]'' "I thought it was only a kind of ''cram'', such as the Dale-men make for journeys in the wild".<ref>{{FR|Farewell}}, p. 369</ref>
